author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Shia LaBeouf ‘He Will Not Divide Us’ exhibit opens in New Mexico
text:
Shia LaBeouf's anti-Trump protest is getting a second act.
A week after the movie star's latest performance-art exhibit — a wall reading "He Will Not Divide Us" in reference to Trump — was shut down in New York , LaBeouf re-opened the display in Albuquerque, New Mexico, on Saturday.
The "Transformers" star was on hand as the new exhibit — still professing the same message — was introduced in the downtown area of Albuquerque on the wall of the El Rey Theater.
"We are anti the normalization of division," LaBeouf said Saturday, according to the Albuquerque Journal. "That's it."
Shia LaBeouf's 'He Will Not Divide Us' shut down due to violence 
13 photos view gallery Shia LaBeouf's most bizarre moments Just like its predecessor, the new "He Will Not Divide Us" wall features a camera below the bold lettering that will feed into a live-stream all day and night for the foreseeable future.
One of the project's co-creators, artist Luke Turner, said the hope is that people will read the wall's message into the camera.
LaBeouf, Turner and fellow artist Nastja Säde Rönkkö first unveiled the exhibit at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens on Jan. 20 — the day of President Trump's inauguration — with the intention of it lasting throughout his term in office.
LaBeouf, who launched the exhibit on Jan. 20, was arrested less than a week later in front of the display after getting into an altercation. (James Keivom/New York Daily News) But the display only made it a few weeks before the museum decided to take it down on Feb. 10, calling it a safety hazard.
Actor Shia LaBeouf arrested at anti-Trump installation in Queens 
"Over the course of the installation, there have been dozens of threats of violence and numerous arrests, such that police felt compelled to be stationed outside the installation 24 hours a day, seven days a week," a statement by the museum read.
The artists claimed in their own statement Saturday that the museum had "bowed to political pressure." In that same statement, the trio announced the piece had moved to Albuquerque, without offering an explanation for how they chose the new destination.
LaBeouf, 30, was arrested during the exhibit's first week last month after a man walked in between the actor and the camera, inciting an altercation, police said.
